So you want to know more about the app, great!

The application was developed with the intention to give everyone a quick and simple way to research university courses across the UK.

If you’re a prospective under/postgraduate then this app will help you find interesting stats to help you choose the course for you.

This is the intriguing part on how the data is used and collected. The app makes the most of services and data provided by: 

•		Firebase
•		Higher Education Statistics Agency
•		National Student Survery
•		Destinations of Leavers from Higher Education Survey.
HESA - Receives information from universities across the UK and collates it into useful information about universities and their courses. For further information goto - HESA

NSS - We also use data from the National Student Survey to collect satisfaction information about the different courses from the students, this is done by Ipsos MORI. This information is collected through a questionnaires. For more information please visit the NSS website at Student Survey

DLFH - is used to find the information about people who have recently left university. The DLHE asks the leavers of courses what they are doing roughly 6 months after the course. For further information goto - HEFCE

Applying for University can seem a daunting task, so here at MyStats the team have put together some tips and hints to help you in your university application journey.

The choice of course is a key decision in anyone’s life with over 37000 courses offered across 350 different universities it can be overwhelming. Below are some tips that will help you choose the right course for you.
Consider Your Enjoyment

Research shows that intrinsically motivating work makes people a lot happier than a big pay cheque so why not pursue a course in the thing you do for fun, your hobby. Whether that’s computer games, gardening, crafts or cooking its worth exploring courses that incorporate your passion rather than concentrating on earning potential alone.

Students often make the mistake of being overly pessimistic or optimistic with their grade expectations, the best way to counter this pitfall is to select courses with a range of entry requirements both high and low to negate the risk of upset come results day.
Apply To A Range
Entry requirements:The choice of location is as important as the course itself, this largely depends on individual circumstances.
Think About Location
Consider Your Career Goals
Choose a course which will help you achieve your long term career goal. There is no point in studying a subject which wont help you get where you want to be after graduating
Do your research
Save yourself unnecessary hard work by checking out what employment stats are like after graduating. Its also worth looking at the kind of careers that will be open to you when finished.
Talk to people

If the facts and figures arent enough try get in touch with some of the institutions alumni most institutions will hand over contact details if you ask. This helps build a fuller picture of what life there would be like not just the academic side of things!
If you are applying for a course through UCAS you are going to have to write a personal Statement. So, to get you started and give you guidance here is some advice to help you.
Your Opening Paragraph

This should be attention grabbing. Don’t use a quote, this is a very generic way to start and isn’t well received this is the first time to draw the person reading in and you want to really blow them away.
Reason to study the course

Say what makes you want to take this course further, talk about how you have been inspired by your current studies and what about the subject you think you will find interesting. If it’s reasonable mention if you have an overall goal.
The course

Give them a reason to choose you, have evidence to back up your reasoning. Show that you have researched the course and how studying at university level will benefit you. Make them aware that you are prepared to take on the responsibility of studying at the higher level.
Extra work

Write about what you’ve done outside any current or previous courses. Talk about any clubs you have been in, any extra studying or reading that you’ve managed to do. Try and talk about using a wide range of media and then give your reflective opinion on the different sources. Don’t mention any extra reading that everyone else is doing.
Current skills

Mention any current skills that will be transferred to the course. Say anything you may excel at, talk about being a good problem solver or how you can work well in a team. Try and tailor the skills to something that would benefit the subject you want to study.
Independent and Analytical work
Briefly talk about any independent work you have done or talk about situations in which you have analytically worked through a problem.
Your Expectations

Say what you hope to get out of the course, talk about any future career plans or what you think the course will give you to set up for life. Talk about how the subject best ties in with your aspirations.
Take your time
Start your personal statement early, this will give you plenty of time to make amendments read it through get it checked by your peers, teachers, parents or any advisors you may see.
Be Excited

Universities read hundreds if not thousands of different students’ personal statements. Make yours stand out by showing your enthusiasm get them to feel exactly how excited you are to go and do their course.
Your Grammar

This is a must, Universities do not like people who use slang, have bad spelling or have sentences that aren’t coherent. Make sure you read it to yourself after you finish, then read it again the next day. Get others to read it, a lot of services are available to get your personal statement checked. Bad English could make or break any candidate.
The Thesaurus

Students often fall into the trap of thinking the admissions staff are excited to see an overused thesaurus it’s better to express yourself with language that you already know and not words that are unfamiliar to you.

University interviews can be intimidating but they aren’t that scary. The most important thing is to be prepared ‘Boy Scout’ style. Click the sections below to find some tips to help you through the big day.
Check for interviews
A University could send you an invitation directly or it could send you one through your UCAS track. Make sure you are checking both regularly so you don\'t miss an appointment by mistake.
Keeping to times and dates

If and where possible keep with the time and date the university have offered you. It is not the end of the world to change an appointment but make sure you do so in good time. Make sure if you do change your interview date and time then you do it directly to the university and not through track.
Prepping

The key here is research; the course, modules and the university are all talking points you should know thoroughly. Make sure you have re-read over your personal statement as this is probably going to be the basis for most of their questions. They will be expecting good students to have questions for them, so have follow up questions to keep the conversation moving.
Travel plans

There’s nothing worse than a late interviewee and planning your travel will avoid this disaster. This is a good opportunity to explore the surrounding area so it’s always best to arrive a few hours early then make sure you’re at the interview room 15 minutes before its due to begin.
What to wear

When picking your interview attire it’s important that you are dressed like you want to be on the course. This doesn’t need to be suited a booted but smart casual is a minimum, most universities will stipulate their expectations so it’s best to call or email ahead of time to ask about the dress code.
Practice

In the end practice will make perfect. Practice interview answers in the mirror, to your friends or with your parents. Try and find somewhere that gives mock interviews at school or college. Someone will be willing to help you and it will help to create the confidence to get you ahead of the competition.
Be yourself
Let your personality show, the university is not expecting the finished product with vast knowledge of the subject but are looking for students that are motivated and show potential.
